SHADER LAB

Bringing pixels to life, one shader at a time

WHAT IS A SHADER?

A shader is a program written in GLSL that is sent to the GPU. It processes how 3D graphics are rendered by handling the positions of a model's vertices and determining how the final image looks on the screen.

There are two main types of shaders: vertex shaders and fragment shaders. The vertex shader determines where each vertex should be positioned on the screen, handling transformations like rotation and scaling. The fragment shader decides the color and appearance of each fragment (a more accurate term than "pixel") of the model, adding effects like textures, lighting, and transparency.
